title: E-commerce Fulfillment and Return Logistics Optimization
content: A rapidly growing e-commerce company needs to deliver online orders to customers while also collecting returned items for restocking or disposal. Trucks must balance the delivery of new products (linehaul) and pickup of returned goods (backhaul) in any sequence, provided the vehicle’s capacity <capacity> isn’t exceeded. The central warehouse and 20 customer locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and return pickups <demand_backhaul>. The goal is to design routes that maximize load efficiency, minimize empty backhaul trips, and ensure all deliveries and pickups are completed without overloading trucks.

title: Construction Material Delivery and Surplus Retrieval Logistics
content: A construction materials supplier delivers building supplies like lumber and cement to active job sites (linehaul) and simultaneously retrieves surplus or damaged materials from completed sites (backhaul). Each truck has a capacity <capacity> and must navigate the mixed backhaul constraint: pickups can occur before or after deliveries as long as sufficient space remains for all linehaul items. The depot and 20 job sites are located at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is to optimize routes to reduce fuel costs and ensure timely material turnover.

title: Agricultural Supply Distribution and Waste Collection
content: An agricultural cooperative delivers fertilizers, seeds, and equipment to farming operations (linehaul) and collects empty containers or agricultural waste (backhaul) for recycling or disposal. Trucks must manage capacity <capacity> while serving 20 farms at <locs>, balancing delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The mixed backhaul allows pickups to precede deliveries if capacity permits, but planners must avoid overloading vehicles by ensuring linehaul items fit before allocating space for backhaul tasks.

title: Pharmaceutical Cold Chain with Expired Product Retrieval
content: A pharmaceutical distributor delivers temperature-sensitive medications to clinics and hospitals (linehaul) and retrieves expired or recalled drugs for safe disposal (backhaul). Each refrigerated truck has a capacity <capacity> and must adhere to the mixed backhaul rule: expired pickups can occur at any point in the route, provided the vehicle retains enough space for all linehaul deliveries. The depot and 20 healthcare sites are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The focus is on route efficiency without compromising product integrity or disposal compliance.

title: Electronics Delivery and Recycling Pickup Logistics
content: An electronics retailer distributes new appliances and gadgets to customers (linehaul) while collecting old devices for recycling (backhaul). Each truck’s capacity <capacity> must accommodate both tasks, with pickups allowed before or after deliveries as long as linehaul items are fully accommodated. The central distribution center and 20 customer locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The goal is to minimize route distances and maximize the reuse of returned electronics while ensuring no vehicle exceeds its capacity.

title: Tool Rental and Return Logistics Optimization
content: A tool rental company needs to deliver equipment to customers and collect returned rentals on the same routes. Each truck must balance outgoing deliveries (linehaul) and incoming pickups (backhaul) without exceeding its capacity. The depot and 20 customer locations are predefined, with delivery demands for tools and pickup demands for returned rentals. The challenge is to plan routes where deliveries and pickups can intermingle, ensuring the vehicle’s capacity <capacity> is never exceeded. For example, a truck might first collect returned drills before delivering ladders, as long as total load stays within limits.

title: Perishable Food Delivery and Organic Waste Collection
content: A food distributor supplies fresh produce to grocery stores while collecting organic waste for composting. Each truck starts at the central warehouse, delivering perishables (linehaul) and picking up waste (backhaul) across 20 locations. The vehicle’s capacity <capacity> must accommodate both outgoing produce and incoming waste, with no strict order between deliveries and pickups. For instance, a truck might drop off milk to a store and then pick up banana peels from a farm before proceeding to the next delivery.

title: Office Equipment Delivery and Recycling Pickup
content: An office supply company delivers new computers and printers to businesses while collecting outdated electronics for recycling. The vehicles must handle mixed loads: linehaul deliveries of equipment and backhaul pickups of e-waste. The depot and 20 customer locations are fixed, with delivery demands for new items and pickup demands for recycling. Routes must ensure that the total weight of deliveries and pickups never exceeds the truck’s capacity <capacity>, allowing flexibility in visit order as long as capacity constraints are met.

title: Event Services
content: A company provides temporary event supplies (e.g., tents, chairs) to venues and later collects them post-event. Trucks must first deliver supplies (linehaul) to setup locations and later retrieve them (backhaul) after events conclude. The depot and 20 event sites are predefined, with delivery and pickup demands. The mixed backhaul allows trucks to interleave deliveries and pickups, such as dropping off tables at one venue and collecting chairs from another, provided the combined load stays within capacity <capacity>.

title: Pallet Delivery and Collection for Manufacturing Plants
content: A logistics firm supplies empty pallets to manufacturing plants and retrieves used, contaminated pallets for sterilization. Each truck must balance outbound linehaul deliveries of clean pallets and inbound backhaul pickups of soiled ones. The depot and 20 plant locations have fixed demands for both types of transactions. The vehicle’s capacity <capacity> must accommodate mixed loads, allowing drivers to alternate between deliveries and pickups as long as total weight remains within limits. For example, a truck might first collect dirty pallets before delivering new ones to the next facility.

title: Home Appliance Delivery and Old Appliance Retrieval Logistics
content: A company delivers new home appliances (e.g., refrigerators, washing machines) to customers while also collecting their old appliances for recycling. Each truck must balance deliveries and pickups along its route. The vehicle’s capacity must ensure that the combined weight of new appliances and collected old units does not exceed its maximum load. The challenge is to optimize routes so that trucks can efficiently serve delivery and pickup customers in any order, while ensuring that the total delivery demands (linehaul) do not exceed capacity before pickups (backhaul) are made. The locations of the warehouse and 20 customer sites are <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>.

title: Event Equipment Delivery and Post-Event Collection Logistics
content: A company provides temporary event equipment (e.g., tents, AV systems, seating) to venues for events and collects it afterward. Trucks must handle both delivering equipment to event locations and retrieving it post-event. The vehicle capacity must accommodate the combined weight of outgoing equipment and incoming returns. Routes must be planned so that deliveries and pickups can occur in any sequence, but the vehicle must ensure sufficient capacity to handle all delivery demands before pickups are made. The warehouse and 20 event sites are located at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>.

title: Industrial Tool Rental and Return Logistics
content: An industrial tool rental company delivers specialized equipment (e.g., power tools, machinery) to construction sites and collects returned tools after use. Each truck must manage both deliveries and pickups along its route. The vehicle’s capacity must account for the total weight of new rentals and returned tools. The route must ensure that all delivery demands (linehaul) are accommodated before pickups (backhaul) are added, even if the order of stops mixes deliveries and pickups. The central depot and 20 customer sites are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>.

title: Restaurant Supply Delivery and Used Container Pickup Logistics
content: A food supply company delivers fresh ingredients to restaurants while collecting empty containers (e.g., crates, barrels) for reuse. Each truck must handle both deliveries and pickups along its route. The vehicle’s capacity must ensure that the combined weight of outgoing supplies and incoming containers stays within limits. The route design allows deliveries and pickups in any order but requires that the total delivery demands (linehaul) do not exceed capacity before pickups (backhaul) are processed. The depot and 20 restaurant locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>.

title: Medical Gas Cylinder Delivery and Empty Cylinder Retrieval Logistics
content: A medical gas supplier delivers oxygen, nitrogen, and other medical-grade cylinders to hospitals and collects empty or spent cylinders for refilling. Each truck must transport full cylinders to healthcare facilities and retrieve empties from other locations. The vehicle’s capacity must balance the weight of outgoing cylinders and incoming empties. The route allows deliveries and pickups in any sequence, but the vehicle must ensure that the total delivery demands (linehaul) are within capacity before pickups (backhaul) are added. The warehouse and 20 healthcare sites are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>.

title: Appliance Repair Services & Spare Parts Recycling Logistics
content: A home appliance repair service company needs to dispatch technicians to customers’ homes to fix appliances. Each technician’s vehicle must deliver spare parts (linehaul) and collect faulty components (backhaul) for recycling. The vehicles have a maximum capacity <capacity>, requiring careful planning to balance the weight of new parts and the volume of old components. The depot location and 20 customer sites are <locs>, with linehaul demands for spare parts <demand_linehaul> and backhaul demands for recycling <demand_backhaul>. Routes must ensure that delivering parts doesn’t overcrowd the vehicle before collecting heavier or bulkier items, while minimizing total distance traveled.

title: Automotive Parts Supply & Used Oil Collection Logistics
content: An automotive parts supplier delivers new components (e.g., filters, tires) to garages and collects used oil or hazardous materials from them for proper disposal. Each vehicle has a capacity <capacity>, and the route must accommodate both deliveries and pickups without exceeding weight limits. The central warehouse and 20 garage locations are <locs>, with linehaul demands for parts <demand_linehaul> and backhaul demands for waste <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is to sequence stops so that the vehicle can handle both tasks efficiently, even if pickups are interspersed with deliveries.

title: Courier Services for Document Delivery and Secure Shredding Pickup
content: A document courier service delivers sensitive files to clients and collects shredded documents from them for secure disposal. Vehicles must carry outgoing deliveries (linehaul) and incoming pickups (backhaul) without exceeding their capacity <capacity>. The depot and 20 client locations are <locs>, with linehaul document volumes <demand_linehaul> and backhaul shredded waste volumes <demand_backhaul>. The mixed backhaul constraint ensures that the vehicle can handle both tasks flexibly, as long as space remains after delivering critical documents.

title: Agricultural Equipment Delivery and Harvest Waste Collection
content: A farm equipment supplier delivers tractors, tools, or seeds to farms (linehaul) and collects post-harvest waste like crop residues or empty pesticide containers (backhaul). Each vehicle has a capacity <capacity>, requiring careful load balancing. The central depot and 20 farm locations are <locs>, with equipment delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and waste collection demands <demand_backhaul>. The mixed backhaul allows pickups and deliveries to be mixed, but the vehicle must ensure it can carry all linehaul items before accommodating backhaul loads.

title: Furniture Delivery and Old Furniture Recycling Pickup
content: A furniture retailer delivers new items to customers’ homes and collects old furniture for recycling or donation. Vehicles must handle bulky deliveries (linehaul) and pickups (backhaul) within their capacity <capacity>. The warehouse and 20 customer addresses are <locs>, with linehaul demands for furniture sizes <demand_linehaul> and backhaul demands for old items <demand_backhaul>. The mixed backhaul flexibility lets drivers interleave deliveries and pickups but must ensure the vehicle can fit all outgoing furniture before accepting returns.

title: Industrial Equipment Delivery and Scrap Metal Pickup Logistics
content: A manufacturing company needs to deliver heavy machinery and spare parts to industrial clients while also collecting scrap metal from their facilities for recycling. Each truck must ensure that the combined weight of outgoing deliveries and incoming scrap does not exceed its maximum capacity. The mixed backhaul allows drivers to interleave deliveries and pickups in any order, provided the vehicle can handle the total load. The depot and 20 client sites are part of the network. Delivery demands include machinery weights, and pickup demands are scrap metal quantities. The goal is to optimize routes to minimize costs while adhering to capacity constraints.

title: Retail Store Inventory Restocking & Returns Logistics
content: A retail chain requires trucks to restock stores with new inventory while collecting returned items for redistribution or disposal. Each vehicle must balance outgoing goods (e.g., clothing, electronics) with incoming returns without exceeding its capacity. The mixed backhaul enables flexible routing, but the vehicle must ensure that deliveries and pickups are sequenced such that total load remains within limits. The depot and 20 retail locations are involved. Delivery demands represent new stock, and pickup demands are returns. The challenge is to design efficient routes that reduce transportation costs and respect capacity limits.

title: Event Catering Supply Delivery and Dish Recycling Logistics
content: A catering service supplies disposable dishes, cutlery, and supplies to event venues while collecting used items for recycling. Trucks must carry both new supplies and return pickups, ensuring their combined weight and volume do not exceed capacity. The mixed backhaul allows drivers to serve delivery and pickup stops in any order, provided the vehicle can handle the combined load. The depot and 20 event locations are part of the network. Delivery demands include catering supplies, and pickups are post-event waste. The objective is to minimize costs while managing capacity constraints.

title: Textile Manufacturer Fabric Delivery and Defective Roll Retrieval
content: A textile producer delivers fabric rolls to garment factories and retrieves defective rolls for quality control or recycling. Each truck must handle both outgoing fabric deliveries and incoming defective rolls without exceeding its capacity. The mixed backhaul permits flexible routing, but the vehicle must ensure that the total load of deliveries and pickups stays within limits. The depot and 20 factory sites are involved. Delivery demands are fabric rolls, and pickup demands are defective rolls. The goal is to optimize routes for cost efficiency while adhering to capacity constraints.

title: Solar Panel Installation and Old Panel Retrieval Logistics
content: A renewable energy firm installs new solar panels at customer sites while collecting old panels for recycling. Trucks must transport new panels to installations and return old ones to the depot, ensuring the total weight of both does not exceed vehicle capacity. The mixed backhaul allows drivers to interleave deliveries and pickups as needed, provided capacity is maintained. The depot and 20 customer locations are part of the network. Delivery demands are new panels, and pickups are outdated or damaged panels. The challenge is to design routes that minimize costs and comply with capacity restrictions.

title: IT Hardware Delivery and E-Waste Recycling Pickup Logistics
content: A tech logistics firm needs to deliver new servers and computers to businesses while simultaneously collecting outdated electronics for recycling. Each vehicle must balance the delivery of new equipment (linehaul) and the pickup of e-waste (backhaul) without exceeding its capacity <capacity>. The depot and 20 customer locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is to optimize routes so that deliveries and pickups are efficiently combined, ensuring that the vehicle’s capacity is never exceeded and that all e-waste is retrieved for proper disposal.

title: Agricultural Seed Delivery and Crop Residue Collection Logistics
content: A farming supply company delivers seeds and fertilizers to rural farms while collecting crop residues (e.g., stalks, husks) for biofuel production. Each truck has a capacity <capacity> and must manage both linehaul deliveries (seeds) and backhaul pickups (residues). The depot and 20 farm locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The goal is to design routes that allow farmers to receive supplies while contributing to sustainable waste management, all while adhering to vehicle capacity limits.

title: Industrial Lubricant Supply and Used Oil Recycling Logistics
content: A lubricant distributor delivers fresh lubricants to manufacturing plants and collects used oil for recycling. Each vehicle must handle linehaul deliveries (lubricants) and backhaul pickups (oil) without overloading. The depot and 20 customer sites are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The task is to plan routes ensuring that lubricant deliveries are prioritized to meet production needs while efficiently integrating oil collection into the same trips, staying within capacity constraints.

title: Home Improvement Supply Delivery and Construction Debris Retrieval
content: A home improvement retailer delivers building materials (e.g., lumber, tiles) to residential customers and collects construction debris (e.g., scrap wood, drywall) for recycling. Each truck has a capacity <capacity> and must balance linehaul deliveries and backhaul pickups. The depot and 20 customer locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is to optimize routes so that customers receive supplies while debris is removed, ensuring that the vehicle’s capacity is never exceeded and routes are cost-effective.

title: Library Book Delivery and Returned Book Collection
content: A library system operates a fleet to deliver new books to branch locations and collect returned books for redistribution or disposal. Each vehicle must manage linehaul deliveries (new books) and backhaul pickups (returns) without exceeding capacity <capacity>. The central depot and 20 branch locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The goal is to design efficient routes that allow libraries to stay stocked while returning books promptly, all while adhering to vehicle capacity limits.

title: Restaurant Linen Delivery and Used Linen Collection Logistics Optimization
content: A hospitality company supplies clean linens (tablecloths, napkins, etc.) to restaurants and hotels while collecting used linens for laundering. Each truck has a maximum capacity <capacity> and must plan routes that allow for mixed deliveries and pickups. The vehicle must ensure that the combined weight of delivered linens and collected used linens never exceeds its capacity. The central warehouse and customer locations <locs> are known, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is to optimize routes so that all linen deliveries are completed efficiently while maximizing the volume of used linens collected, without overloading trucks.

title: Agricultural Chemical Delivery and Empty Container Recycling Logistics
content: A farm supply business delivers pesticides and fertilizers to agricultural customers while collecting empty chemical containers for safe disposal. Each truck with capacity <capacity> must visit farms and distribution centers, delivering chemicals first or interleaving pickups of empty containers. The vehicle must ensure that the total weight of delivered chemicals plus collected containers does not exceed capacity at any point. The depot and customer locations <locs> are fixed, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> (chemicals) and pickup demands <demand_backhaul> (empty containers). The goal is to minimize travel costs while ensuring all deliveries and pickups are completed within capacity limits.

title: Construction Equipment Rental and Return Logistics
content: A construction equipment rental company delivers machinery (e.g., excavators, generators) to job sites and later retrieves them for redistribution. Each truck has a capacity <capacity> and must plan routes that allow for both deliveries and pickups in any order. The vehicle must ensure that the combined weight of delivered equipment and returned equipment does not exceed capacity. The depot and customer locations <locs> are known, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is to optimize routes to serve multiple job sites efficiently while managing mixed loads and ensuring timely equipment turnover.

title: Emergency Supplies Delivery and Hazardous Waste Collection Logistics
content: A disaster relief logistics firm delivers medical kits, water, and food to affected areas while collecting hazardous waste (e.g., contaminated materials, medical waste) for disposal. Each truck with capacity <capacity> must balance deliveries and pickups along routes, ensuring that the total weight of supplies delivered plus hazardous waste collected stays within capacity. The depot and disaster-affected locations <locs> are fixed, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The goal is to maximize coverage of critical zones while adhering to capacity constraints and prioritizing urgent deliveries.

title: School Supplies Delivery and Obsolete Electronics Recycling Pickup Logistics
content: An educational supply provider delivers textbooks and devices to schools while collecting outdated electronics (e.g., old laptops, printers) for recycling. Each truck has a capacity <capacity> and must plan routes that allow for mixed deliveries and pickups. The vehicle must ensure that the combined weight of new supplies and recycled electronics does not exceed capacity. The depot and school locations <locs> are known, with delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is to optimize routes to efficiently serve all schools while maximizing the volume of obsolete electronics collected for recycling.

title: Film Production Equipment Delivery and Post-Shoot Retrieval Logistics
content: A film production logistics company operates a fleet of trucks to deliver filming equipment to locations and collect used gear after shoots. Each truck has a maximum capacity of `<capacity>` and must manage mixed backhauls, allowing deliveries and pickups in any order. However, the total weight of delivered equipment (linehaul) plus collected gear (backhaul) must not exceed the vehicle's capacity. The warehouse and 20 filming sites' locations are `<locs>`, with delivery demands of `<demand_linehaul>` and pickup demands of `<demand_backhaul>`. The challenge is to plan routes that ensure all equipment is delivered and retrieved efficiently while keeping costs low and avoiding overloading any truck.

title: University Lab Equipment Delivery and Chemical Waste Retrieval Logistics
content: A university's logistics team uses trucks to deliver scientific equipment to research labs and collect hazardous chemical waste for disposal. Each truck has a capacity of `<capacity>`, and must handle both linehaul deliveries (equipment) and backhaul pickups (waste). The vehicle must ensure that the combined weight of equipment and waste doesn't exceed capacity. The central warehouse and 20 lab locations are at `<locs>`, with delivery demands `<demand_linehaul>` and pickup demands `<demand_backhaul>`. The goal is to optimize routes so that all labs receive equipment and waste is collected efficiently without exceeding truck capacities.

title: Home Heating Oil Delivery and Empty Tank Collection Logistics
content: A heating oil supplier delivers fuel to residential customers and collects empty storage tanks for refilling. Each truck has a capacity of `<capacity>` and must manage mixed backhauls, delivering oil first and then picking up empty tanks. The total load (oil plus tanks) must stay within capacity limits. The warehouse and 20 customer locations are at `<locs>`, with delivery demands `<demand_linehaul>` and pickup demands `<demand_backhaul>`. The challenge is to plan routes that ensure timely oil deliveries and efficient tank collection while minimizing fuel and labor costs.

title: Event Decoration Delivery and Post-Event Collection Logistics
content: An event decoration company transports floral arrangements, banners, and props to venues and retrieves them after events. Each truck has a capacity of `<capacity>` and must handle both deliveries (linehaul) and pickups (backhaul) in any order, provided the total weight doesn't exceed capacity. The central warehouse and 20 event locations are at `<locs>`, with delivery demands `<demand_linehaul>` and pickup demands `<demand_backhaul>`. The goal is to optimize routes to minimize transportation costs while ensuring all decorations are delivered and collected efficiently.

title: Industrial Repair Services and Scrap Metal Pickup Logistics
content: A repair service company delivers tools and spare parts to factories for maintenance and collects scrap metal from the same sites for recycling. Each truck has a capacity of `<capacity>` and must manage mixed backhauls, allowing deliveries and pickups in any sequence. The total weight of parts delivered plus scrap collected must not exceed the truck's capacity. The warehouse and 20 industrial sites are at `<locs>`, with delivery demands `<demand_linehaul>` and pickup demands `<demand_backhaul>`. The challenge is to plan routes that balance delivery and pickup demands efficiently to reduce costs and ensure all sites are serviced within capacity limits.

title: Farm Equipment Rental & Soil Sample Collection Logistics
content: A farm equipment rental company delivers tractors, tools, and machinery to agricultural customers while simultaneously collecting soil samples for analysis from their fields. Each vehicle has a maximum capacity \( Q \), requiring the total weight of equipment deliveries and soil samples to stay within limits. The mixed backhaul allows deliveries and pickups to be sequenced flexibly, but the vehicle must ensure sufficient capacity remains after linehaul (equipment) deliveries to accommodate backhaul (soil sample) pickups. The depot and 20 customer locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands of <demand_linehaul> (e.g., machinery) and pickup demands of <demand_backhaul> (e.g., soil containers). The goal is to minimize travel costs while ensuring all equipment is delivered and samples are collected without exceeding capacity.

title: Winery Supply Delivery & Grape Waste Collection Optimization
content: A winery logistics provider must deliver glass bottles, corks, and packaging materials to vineyards while also collecting grape pomace (post-harvest waste) for composting or energy production. Each truck’s capacity \( Q \) must balance the weight of outgoing supplies (linehaul) and incoming waste (backhaul). The mixed backhaul constraint permits any delivery-pickup sequence, provided the vehicle does not exceed capacity after servicing linehaul customers. The depot and 20 vineyard locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands of <demand_linehaul> (supplies) and pickup demands of <demand_backhaul> (waste). The challenge is to design routes that maximize efficiency while adhering to capacity limits and supporting sustainable waste management.

title: Restaurant Kitchen Equipment Delivery & Used Cooking Oil Recycling Logistics
content: A commercial kitchen equipment supplier delivers grills, fryers, and storage units to restaurants while also collecting used cooking oil for recycling. Each vehicle’s capacity \( Q \) must account for both heavy equipment deliveries (linehaul) and the volume of oil drums (backhaul). The mixed backhaul allows pickups and deliveries to be intermixed, but the vehicle must ensure sufficient residual capacity after linehaul stops to handle backhaul pickups. The depot and 20 restaurant locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands of <demand_linehaul> (equipment) and pickup demands of <demand_backhaul> (oil containers). The aim is to optimize routes to reduce fuel use and streamline waste-to-resource recycling.

title: Construction Site Material Delivery & Waste Recycling Pickup Logistics
content: A construction logistics firm supplies building materials (e.g., lumber, drywall) to active job sites while collecting construction debris (e.g., scrap metal, wood scraps) for recycling. Each truck’s capacity \( Q \) must balance the outbound materials and inbound waste. The mixed backhaul allows any sequence of deliveries and pickups, but the vehicle must ensure linehaul (material) deliveries do not consume all capacity before accommodating backhaul (waste) pickups. The depot and 20 sites are at <locs>, with delivery demands of <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands of <demand_backhaul>. The focus is on minimizing transportation costs while supporting circular economy practices.

title: Aquaculture Feed Distribution & Fish Processing Waste Retrieval Logistics
content: An aquaculture supplier delivers fish feed to fish farms and collects fish byproducts (e.g., scales, bones) for processing into animal feed or biofuel. Each vehicle’s capacity \( Q \) must account for the weight of feed (linehaul) and the volume of waste (backhaul). The mixed backhaul permits flexible routing, but the vehicle must reserve capacity for backhaul pickups after delivering linehaul supplies. The depot and 20 farm locations are at <locs>, with delivery demands of <demand_linehaul> and pickup demands of <demand_backhaul>. The goal is to optimize routes for cost efficiency while ensuring waste is retrieved promptly to prevent spoilage.

title: Animal Feed Delivery and Manure Collection Logistics
content: A livestock feed supplier needs to deliver feed to farms and collect manure for composting. Each truck must first deliver feed to linehaul customers (farms needing supplies) and then collect manure from backhaul customers (farms with waste). The mixed backhaul constraint ensures that trucks can visit both types of customers in any order, provided the total weight of feed deliveries and manure pickups never exceeds the vehicle’s capacity <capacity>. The locations of the central depot and 20 farms are <locs>, with feed delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and manure pickup amounts <demand_backhaul> specified per farm. The goal is optimizing routes to minimize transportation costs while adhering to capacity limits.

title: Landscaping Supply Delivery and Yard Waste Pickup Logistics
content: A landscaping company delivers mulch, plants, and gardening tools to residential and commercial customers while collecting yard waste (e.g., leaves, branches) for disposal. Each vehicle must balance deliveries and pickups without exceeding its capacity <capacity>. The mixed backhaul approach allows trucks to serve customers in any sequence, as long as the combined weight of supplies and waste stays within limits. The depot locations and 20 customer sites are <locs>, with supply delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and waste pickup requirements <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is creating efficient routes to reduce fuel costs and ensure all services are completed within capacity constraints.

title: School Book Delivery and Textbook Recycling Pickup Logistics
content: An educational supply distributor delivers new textbooks and school supplies to schools and collects outdated or damaged textbooks for recycling. Each truck must handle both deliveries and pickups, ensuring that the total weight of new books and recycled materials does not exceed capacity <capacity>. The mixed backhaul model allows flexible routing, as long as capacity is maintained. The depot locations and 20 schools are <locs>, with textbook delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and recycling pickup amounts <demand_backhaul> specified. The objective is to optimize routes for cost efficiency while managing capacity across all stops.

title: Medical Equipment Delivery and Sample Collection Logistics
content: A healthcare logistics firm delivers medical devices and supplies to clinics while collecting blood or diagnostic samples for laboratory analysis. Each vehicle must first deliver equipment to linehaul customers (clinics) and can then collect samples from backhaul customers (health facilities) in any order, provided the combined weight of deliveries and pickups stays within capacity <capacity>. The depot locations and 20 healthcare sites are <locs>, with equipment delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and sample pickup requirements <demand_backhaul>. The goal is designing routes to minimize travel costs and ensure all medical services are fulfilled efficiently.

title: Battery Delivery and Recycling Pickup Logistics
content: An energy company delivers new batteries (e.g., for electric vehicles or solar systems) to customers and collects used batteries for recycling. Each truck must balance deliveries of new batteries and pickups of old ones without exceeding capacity <capacity>. The mixed backhaul constraint allows flexible routing, as long as the total load remains within limits. The depot locations and 20 customer sites are <locs>, with battery delivery demands <demand_linehaul> and recycling pickup amounts <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is optimizing routes to reduce transportation costs while adhering to capacity constraints and ensuring efficient waste management.

title: Curbside Recycling Container Delivery and Collection Logistics Optimization
content: My company manages a municipal recycling program that delivers empty bins to households and collects filled containers for processing. Each truck has a maximum capacity <capacity>, so we must ensure that the combined weight of delivered containers and collected waste never exceeds this limit. The trucks can interleave deliveries and pickups in any order, but must always account for the total load. The depot and 20 residential locations are <locs>. The delivery demand for empty bins is <demand_linehaul>, and the pickup demand for filled containers is <demand_backhaul>. The goal is to design routes that efficiently serve all households while minimizing fuel costs and avoiding overloading.

title: Restaurant Equipment Rental and Return Logistics Optimization
content: We rent commercial kitchen equipment to restaurants and need to deliver new units while collecting returned rentals for maintenance. Each truck has a capacity <capacity>, so we must balance the weight of outgoing equipment deliveries and incoming returns. The route can mix deliveries and pickups, but the total load must stay within limits. The depot and 20 restaurant customers are <locs>. The delivery demand for new equipment is <demand_linehaul>, and the pickup demand for returned items is <demand_backhaul>. The challenge is to optimize routes for efficiency while ensuring no truck exceeds its capacity.

title: School Lab Equipment Delivery and Old Equipment Retrieval Logistics Optimization
content: I manage a school supply company that delivers new lab equipment to educational institutions and collects outdated gear for recycling. Each truck has a capacity <capacity>, so the combined weight of new deliveries and old pickups must not exceed this limit. Trucks can visit delivery and pickup locations in any sequence but must track load constraints. The depot and 20 schools' locations are <locs>. The delivery demand for new equipment is <demand_linehaul>, and the pickup demand for obsolete items is <demand_backhaul>. The plan must ensure all schools are served without overloading vehicles.

title: Electronics Disposal and New Product Delivery Logistics Optimization
content: My electronics retailer delivers new devices to customers while collecting old units for recycling. Each truck has a capacity <capacity>, so we must manage the weight of outgoing deliveries and incoming pickups. The route can mix both tasks, but the total load must stay under capacity. The depot and 20 customer locations are <locs>. The delivery demand for new electronics is <demand_linehaul>, and the pickup demand for old devices is <demand_backhaul>. The goal is to minimize travel costs while adhering to load limits and ensuring efficient reverse logistics.

title: Automotive Service Parts Delivery and Salvage Material Pickup Logistics Optimization
content: An automotive repair network delivers replacement parts to shops while collecting salvageable materials (e.g., scrap metal, old tires) for recycling. Each truck has a capacity <capacity>, so we must balance the weight of parts deliveries and salvage pickups. The route can interleave both tasks, but the total load must not exceed capacity. The depot and 20 repair shops’ locations are <locs>. The delivery demand for parts is <demand_linehaul>, and the pickup demand for salvage is <demand_backhaul>.
